elements.content: We report the proton conduction properties of a 2D flexible MOF and a 1D coordination polymer having the molecular formulas {[Zn(C10H2O8)0.5(C10S2N2H8)]·5H2O]} n (1) and {[Zn(C10H2O8)0.5(C10S2N2H8)]·2H2O]} n (2), respectively. Compounds 1 and 2 show high conductivity values of 2.55 × 10–7 and 4.39 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 80 °C and 95% RH. The conductivity value of compound 1 is in the range of those for previously reported flexible MOFs, and compound 2 shows the highest proton conductivity among the carboxylate-based 1D CPs. The dimensionality and the internal hydrogen bonding connectivity play a vital role in the resultant conductivity. Variable-temperature experiments of both compounds at high humidity reveal that the conductivity values increase with increasing temperature, whereas the variable humidity studies signify the influence of relative humidity on high-temperature proton conductivity. The time-dependent measurements for both compounds demonstrate their ability to retain conductivity up to 10 h.
elements.clean_text: We report the proton conduction properties of a 2D flexible MOF and a 1D coordination polymer having the molecular formulas {[Zn(C10H2O8)0.5(C10S2N2H8)]⋅5H2O]} n  (1) and {[Zn(C10H2O8)0.5(C10S2N2H8)]⋅2H2O]} n  (2), respectively. Compounds 1 and 2 show high conductivity values of 2.55 × 10-7 and 4.39 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 80 °C and 95% RH. The conductivity value of compound 1 is in the range of those for previously reported flexible MOFs, and compound 2 shows the highest proton conductivity among the carboxylate-based 1D CPs. The dimensionality and the internal hydrogen bonding connectivity play a vital role in the resultant conductivity. Variable-temperature experiments of both compounds at high humidity reveal that the conductivity values increase with increasing temperature, whereas the variable humidity studies signify the influence of relative humidity on high-temperature proton conductivity. The time-dependent measurements for both compounds demonstrate their ability to retain conductivity up to 10 h.

elements.content: A 2D flexible MOF and 1D coordination polymer show proton conduction at high temperatures and high humidity. The time-dependent conductivity measurements reveal their conducting ability continuously for 10 h.
elements.clean_text: A 2D flexible MOF and 1D coordination polymer show proton conduction at high temperatures and high humidity. The time-dependent conductivity measurements reveal their conducting ability continuously for 10 h.

elements.content: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are a new class of exciting materials that have been explored for a wide variety of popular applications such as gas sorption, magnetism, catalysis, drug delivery, etc. Apart from their conventional applications MOFs also have potential as proton conductors in fuel cells. Recently, the proton conduction phenomenon in MOFs has been extensively investigated by various research groups such as those of Shimizu, Kitagawa, and others. The main advantages of MOFs in comparison to other proton-conducting materials (such as Nafion, mesoporous silica, and organic porous solids) are their designable structures with tunable functionalities in addition to the their chemical and thermal stability. Several MOFs exhibit proton conductivity in the range of 10–7–10–3 at room temperature under anhydrous as well as high-humidity conditions. Additionally, many MOFs have been reported which show proton conductivity at higher temperatures and high-humidity conditions, which is the most important requirement for its practical application in fuel cell membranes. Apart from the conventional MOFs, several third-generation flexible MOFs have been reported in the literature which are well-known for selective, stepwise adsorption and separation of gases and solvent vapors. However, very few flexible MOFs have been reported for proton conduction (e.g., the MIL series).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are a new class of exciting materials that have been explored for a wide variety of popular applications such as gas sorption, magnetism, catalysis, drug delivery, etc. Apart from their conventional applications MOFs also have potential as proton conductors in fuel cells. Recently, the proton conduction phenomenon in MOFs has been extensively investigated by various research groups such as those of Shimizu, Kitagawa, and others. The main advantages of MOFs in comparison to other proton-conducting materials (such as Nafion, mesoporous silica, and organic porous solids) are their designable structures with tunable functionalities in addition to the their chemical and thermal stability. Several MOFs exhibit proton conductivity in the range of 10-7-10-3 at room temperature under anhydrous as well as high-humidity conditions. Additionally, many MOFs have been reported which show proton conductivity at higher temperatures and high-humidity conditions, which is the most important requirement for its practical application in fuel cell membranes. Apart from the conventional MOFs, several third-generation flexible MOFs have been reported in the literature which are well-known for selective, stepwise adsorption and separation of gases and solvent vapors. However, very few flexible MOFs have been reported for proton conduction (e.g., the MIL series).

elements.content: In this context, we explored the proton conduction behavior of a 2D flexible MOF and a 1D coordination polymer having the formulas {[Zn(C10H2O8)0.5(C10S2N2H8)] ·5H2O]} n (1) and {[Zn(C10H2O8)0.5(C10S2N2H8)]·2H2O]} n (2), respectively. Compounds 1 and 2 show respective conductivity values of 2.55 × 10–7 and 4.39 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 80 °C and 95% RH. In addition, we also investigated the time-dependent proton conduction properties of both compounds, and the results show that they are able to retain their conductivity up to 10 h at 80 °C and 95% RH. The observed proton conductivities and durability of both compounds demonstrates their ability for practical applications.
elements.clean_text: In this context, we explored the proton conduction behavior of a 2D flexible MOF and a 1D coordination polymer having the formulas {[Zn(C10H2O8)0.5(C10S2N2H8)] ⋅5H2O]} n  (1) and {[Zn(C10H2O8)0.5(C10S2N2H8)]⋅2H2O]} n  (2), respectively. Compounds 1 and 2 show respective conductivity values of 2.55 × 10-7 and 4.39 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 80 °C and 95% RH. In addition, we also investigated the time-dependent proton conduction properties of both compounds, and the results show that they are able to retain their conductivity up to 10 h at 80 °C and 95% RH. The observed proton conductivities and durability of both compounds demonstrates their ability for practical applications.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis data were recorded on a PerkinElmer TGA 4000 instrument in the temperature range of 30–500 °C under an N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. PXRD patterns were taken on a PAnalytical EMPYRIAN instrument by using Cu Kα radiation. DSC patterns were recorded on a PerkinElmer DSC 6000 instrument.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Physical Measurements

Thermogravimetric analysis data were recorded on a PerkinElmer TGA 4000 instrument in the temperature range of 30-500 °C under an N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. PXRD patterns were taken on a PAnalytical EMPYRIAN instrument by using Cu Kα radiation. DSC patterns were recorded on a PerkinElmer DSC 6000 instrument.

elements.content: The proton conductivity of the compounds was measured by a quasi-four-probe method using a Solartron SI 1260 Impedance/Gain-Phase Analyzer and 1296 Dielectric Interface, in the frequency range of 1 Hz to 1 MHz. For sample preparation, ∼130 mg of the as-synthesized samples were finely ground and then pressed in a pellet maker to obtain uniform pellets of 0.42–0.46 mm thickness and 13 mm diameter at 10 tons of pressure. The temperature and humidity were controlled by a programmable incubator (JEIOTECH, TH-PE series). Samples were equilibrated for at least 8 h after each step in temperature and 12 h after each step in humidity. All of the operations were computer-controlled and automatic. The resistances were calculated from the semicircles of the Nyquist plots. Proton conductivity was calculated from the equation σ = L/(R A) where σ = proton conductivity, L = thickness of the pellet, R = resistance of the pellet measured, and A = area of the pellet = πr 2 (r = radius of the pellet). The activation energy values were determined from the slope of Arrhenius plots by least-squares fitting.
elements.clean_text:
Conductivity Measurements

The proton conductivity of the compounds was measured by a quasi-four-probe method using a Solartron SI 1260 Impedance/Gain-Phase Analyzer and 1296 Dielectric Interface, in the frequency range of 1 Hz to 1 MHz. For sample preparation, ~130 mg of the as-synthesized samples were finely ground and then pressed in a pellet maker to obtain uniform pellets of 0.42-0.46 mm thickness and 13 mm diameter at 10 tons of pressure. The temperature and humidity were controlled by a programmable incubator (JEIOTECH, TH-PE series). Samples were equilibrated for at least 8 h after each step in temperature and 12 h after each step in humidity. All of the operations were computer-controlled and automatic. The resistances were calculated from the semicircles of the Nyquist plots. Proton conductivity was calculated from the equation σ = L/(R A) where σ = proton conductivity, L = thickness of the pellet, R = resistance of the pellet measured, and A = area of the pellet = πr 2 (r = radius of the pellet). The activation energy values were determined from the slope of Arrhenius plots by least-squares fitting.

elements.content: Material Studio version 6.1 was used for water adsorption simulations. New CIF files were generated after removing the lattice water molecules in both compounds, and the files were incorporated into the program files. The program with the Sorption module was run to generate the simulated adsorption isotherms as well as the possible water accumulation inside the frameworks. The Monte Carlo method was used for these calculations. The output files are given in the for a better understanding.
elements.clean_text:
Simulation Details

Material Studio version 6.1 was used for water adsorption simulations. New CIF files were generated after removing the lattice water molecules in both compounds, and the files were incorporated into the program files. The program with the Sorption module was run to generate the simulated adsorption isotherms as well as the possible water accumulation inside the frameworks. The Monte Carlo method was used for these calculations. The output files are given in the  for a better understanding.

elements.content: Compound 1 was synthesized by the reaction of pyromellitate and aldrithiol with Zn(NO3)2·6H2O through a slow diffusion technique, whereas 2 was prepared by a hydrothermal reaction at high temperature (160 °C). A detailed structural description, characterization, and adsorption properties of both compounds have already been reported. In brief, compound 1 has a 2D layered structure with five lattice water molecules per formula unit (Figure ), whereas compound 2 is a 1D coordination polymer possessing two lattice water molecules (Figure ). It is interesting to note that, in 1, the four lattice water molecules (O9, O10, O11, O16) which are between the 2D layers are involved in the formation of continuous and fused H-bonded rings (five, five, and six membered) with the contribution from acidic carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2), whereas in 2, both water molecules (O9, O11) form a linear zigzag chain (Figures S1 and S2, ). Additionally, in both compounds, out of eight oxygen atoms of the pyromellitate ligand, four do not participate in coordination to the metal centers but are involved in hydrogen-bonding interactions through lattice H2O molecules (Figures S3 and S4, ). A packing view of compound 1 reveals that the 2D layers consist of 1D channels that run along the b axis, whereas 2 possesses 1D channels along the a axis. In both compounds, the observed 1D channels are occupied by lattice H2O molecules and free oxygen atoms of the carboxylate group of pyromellitate ligands are protruding into the 1D channels, making them hydrated in nature. Water adsorption studies reveal that compound 1 shows a two-step adsorption isotherm with an adsorption amount of 109.5 mL g–1 and compound 2 attains a value of 80 mL g–1 (Figures S5 and S6, ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Compound 1 was synthesized by the reaction of pyromellitate and aldrithiol with Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O through a slow diffusion technique, whereas 2 was prepared by a hydrothermal reaction at high temperature (160 °C). A detailed structural description, characterization, and adsorption properties of both compounds have already been reported. In brief, compound 1 has a 2D layered structure with five lattice water molecules per formula unit (Figure ), whereas compound 2 is a 1D coordination polymer possessing two lattice water molecules (Figure ). It is interesting to note that, in 1, the four lattice water molecules (O9, O10, O11, O16) which are between the 2D layers are involved in the formation of continuous and fused H-bonded rings (five, five, and six membered) with the contribution from acidic carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2), whereas in 2, both water molecules (O9, O11) form a linear zigzag chain (Figures S1 and S2, ). Additionally, in both compounds, out of eight oxygen atoms of the pyromellitate ligand, four do not participate in coordination to the metal centers but are involved in hydrogen-bonding interactions through lattice H2O molecules (Figures S3 and S4, ). A packing view of compound 1 reveals that the 2D layers consist of 1D channels that run along the b axis, whereas 2 possesses 1D channels along the a axis. In both compounds, the observed 1D channels are occupied by lattice H2O molecules and free oxygen atoms of the carboxylate group of pyromellitate ligands are protruding into the 1D channels, making them hydrated in nature. Water adsorption studies reveal that compound 1 shows a two-step adsorption isotherm with an adsorption amount of 109.5 mL g-1 and compound 2 attains a value of 80 mL g-1 (Figures S5 and S6, ).

elements.content: 2D layered structure of compound 1 (top) and its hydrogen-bonding network among the lattice water molecules (bottom). Color code: C, cyan; N, blue; O, red; S, yellow; Zn, green.
elements.clean_text: 1  2D layered structure of compound 1 (top) and its hydrogen-bonding network among the lattice water molecules (bottom). Color code: C, cyan; N, blue; O, red; S, yellow; Zn, green.

elements.content: 1D chain of compound 2 (top) and its hydrogen-bonding network among the lattice water molecules (bottom). The color code is the same as in Figure .
elements.clean_text: 2  1D chain of compound 2 (top) and its hydrogen-bonding network among the lattice water molecules (bottom). The color code is the same as in Figure .

elements.content: Our earlier reports suggest that compounds 1 and 2 lose their lattice water molecules in the temperature ranges of 100–125 and 90–200 °C, respectively. The phase purity of both samples in bulk was confirmed by comparing the PXRD patterns of the as-synthesized compounds with their corresponding simulated patterns (Figures S7 and S8 and Tables S1 and S2, ). The variable-temperature PXRD patterns of compounds 1 and 2 were recorded in the range of 25–85 °C and were also successfully indexed by using the TREOR program in Material Studio 6.1. (Figures S9 and S10 and Tables S3 and S4, ).
elements.clean_text: Our earlier reports suggest that compounds 1 and 2 lose their lattice water molecules in the temperature ranges of 100-125 and 90-200 °C, respectively. The phase purity of both samples in bulk was confirmed by comparing the PXRD patterns of the as-synthesized compounds with their corresponding simulated patterns (Figures S7 and S8 and Tables S1 and S2, ). The variable-temperature PXRD patterns of compounds 1 and 2 were recorded in the range of 25-85 °C and were also successfully indexed by using the TREOR program in Material Studio 6.1. (Figures S9 and S10 and Tables S3 and S4, ).

elements.content: From the unit cell parameters (obtained from powder indexing), we confirmed that the compounds are stable at 85 °C and there no structural changes happen in the frameworks. To check the structural stability toward higher temperatures and high-humidity conditions, compounds were kept in a humidity chamber at 80 °C and 95% RH for 12 h and subsequently the PXRD patterns were recorded (Figures S11 and S12, ). All of the major experimental peaks were found to match well with the as-synthesized compounds. Indexing of the respective patterns showed that the unit cell parameters are in accordance with the single-crystal data, which further confirmed the structural integrity of compounds 1 and 2 (Tables S5 and S6, ). To investigate any phase change, we recorded the DSC patterns in the temperature range of 30–400 °C and the patterns show the first endothermic peaks in the range of 35–113 °C for 1 and 35–125 °C for 2. The observed peaks are due to the loss of guest water molecules. Compounds 1 and 2 undergo irreversible phase transformation above 120 and 220 °C in order, and that has been confirmed by second endothermic peaks at 125 and 225 °C for 1 and 2, respectively (Figures S13 and S14, ).
elements.clean_text: From the unit cell parameters (obtained from powder indexing), we confirmed that the compounds are stable at 85 °C and there no structural changes happen in the frameworks. To check the structural stability toward higher temperatures and high-humidity conditions, compounds were kept in a humidity chamber at 80 °C and 95% RH for 12 h and subsequently the PXRD patterns were recorded (Figures S11 and S12, ). All of the major experimental peaks were found to match well with the as-synthesized compounds. Indexing of the respective patterns showed that the unit cell parameters are in accordance with the single-crystal data, which further confirmed the structural integrity of compounds 1 and 2 (Tables S5 and S6, ). To investigate any phase change, we recorded the DSC patterns in the temperature range of 30-400 °C and the patterns show the first endothermic peaks in the range of 35-113 °C for 1 and 35-125 °C for 2. The observed peaks are due to the loss of guest water molecules. Compounds 1 and 2 undergo irreversible phase transformation above 120 and 220 °C in order, and that has been confirmed by second endothermic peaks at 125 and 225 °C for 1 and 2, respectively (Figures S13 and S14, ).

elements.content: To determine the structural stability of the compounds under high-humidiy conditions, both compounds were immersed in water for 24 h and the PXRD patterns were recorded upon drying. Both patterns were in very good correspondence with the as-synthesized compounds, which is also justified by the powder indexing results, thus confirming the water stability of both compounds (Figures S15 and S16 and Tables S7 and S8, ).
elements.clean_text: To determine the structural stability of the compounds under high-humidiy conditions, both compounds were immersed in water for 24 h and the PXRD patterns were recorded upon drying. Both patterns were in very good correspondence with the as-synthesized compounds, which is also justified by the powder indexing results, thus confirming the water stability of both compounds (Figures S15 and S16 and Tables S7 and S8, ).

elements.content: It has been reported that the proton conduction in MOFs can be divided mainly into two categories. The first category is water-mediated proton conduction, where the conductivity depends on the presence of water molecules or the hydrogen-bonding connectivity in the framework (operating in the temperature range of 20–80 °C). The second category is anhydrous proton conduction, where the conductivity is due to the organic moieties which are incorporated as guest molecules (operates at >100 °C). The presence of lattice water molecules as well as their continuous hydrogen-bonding connectivity in the frameworks motivated us to investigate the proton conduction behavior of both compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Proton Conductivity Studies

It has been reported that the proton conduction in MOFs can be divided mainly into two categories. The first category is water-mediated proton conduction, where the conductivity depends on the presence of water molecules or the hydrogen-bonding connectivity in the framework (operating in the temperature range of 20-80 °C). The second category is anhydrous proton conduction, where the conductivity is due to the organic moieties which are incorporated as guest molecules (operates at >100 °C). The presence of lattice water molecules as well as their continuous hydrogen-bonding connectivity in the frameworks motivated us to investigate the proton conduction behavior of both compounds.

elements.content: Proton conduction in compounds 1 and 2 was measured by alternating current (ac) impedance spectroscopy. The as-synthesized compounds do not show any proton conductivity under anhydrous conditions at 25 °C. However, after 24 h of humidification both compounds start showing proton conductivity, which reveals the role of the H2O molecule as a proton carrier. The proton conductivities of compounds 1 and 2 were determined from the semicircles in the high-frequency regions of Nyquist plots, which correspond to both bulk and grain boundary resistance, and the tail in the low-frequency region is due to blocking effects at the electrode–electrolyte interface. Compound 1 shows proton conductivity of 5.23 × 10–10 S cm–1 at 25 °C and 95% RH (Figure S17, ), and the conductivity value increases with increasing temperature (Figure S18, ) and reaches a maximum value of 2.55 × 10–7 S cm–1 at 80 °C and 95% RH, which is quite close to the value for the previously reported MIL-53 series flexible MOFs (3.6 × 10–7 S cm–1) under similar conditions (Figure ). Compound 2 shows proton conductivity of 1.33 × 10–7 S cm–1 at 25 °C and 95% RH (Figure S19, ), and the value increases with an increase in temperature (Figure S20, ) and saturates with a value of 4.39 × 10–4 S cm–1 (at 80 °C and 95% RH) (Figure ). To the best of our knowledge, compound 2 shows the highest proton conductivity to date among the reported carboxylate-based 1D CPs (at 80 °C, 95% RH). However, the value is lower than that of phosphonate-based MOFs reported (2.1 × 10–2 S cm–1 at 90% RH and 85 °C) by Shimizu et al. It is worth mentioning that, in both compounds, the proton conductivity increases with an increase in temperature. To probe and gain more insight into the proton conduction mechanism, we calculated the activation energies for proton conduction of compounds 1 and 2 from the Arrhenius equation. As determined from least-squares fits of the slopes of Arrhenius plots, the activation energies of compounds 1 and 2 were 0.96 and 0.84 eV, respectively (Figure ) and from these values it is concluded that the observed proton conductivities follow the Vehicle mechanism.
elements.clean_text: Proton conduction in compounds 1 and 2 was measured by alternating current (ac) impedance spectroscopy. The as-synthesized compounds do not show any proton conductivity under anhydrous conditions at 25 °C. However, after 24 h of humidification both compounds start showing proton conductivity, which reveals the role of the H2O molecule as a proton carrier. The proton conductivities of compounds 1 and 2 were determined from the semicircles in the high-frequency regions of Nyquist plots, which correspond to both bulk and grain boundary resistance, and the tail in the low-frequency region is due to blocking effects at the electrode-electrolyte interface. Compound 1 shows proton conductivity of 5.23 × 10-10 S cm-1 at 25 °C and 95% RH (Figure S17, ), and the conductivity value increases with increasing temperature (Figure S18, ) and reaches a maximum value of 2.55 × 10-7 S cm-1 at 80 °C and 95% RH, which is quite close to the value for the previously reported MIL-53 series flexible MOFs (3.6 × 10-7 S cm-1) under similar conditions (Figure ). Compound 2 shows proton conductivity of 1.33 × 10-7 S cm-1 at 25 °C and 95% RH (Figure S19, ), and the value increases with an increase in temperature (Figure S20, ) and saturates with a value of 4.39 × 10-4 S cm-1 (at 80 °C and 95% RH) (Figure ). To the best of our knowledge, compound 2 shows the highest proton conductivity to date among the reported carboxylate-based 1D CPs (at 80 °C, 95% RH). However, the value is lower than that of phosphonate-based MOFs reported (2.1 × 10-2 S cm-1 at 90% RH and 85 °C) by Shimizu et al. It is worth mentioning that, in both compounds, the proton conductivity increases with an increase in temperature. To probe and gain more insight into the proton conduction mechanism, we calculated the activation energies for proton conduction of compounds 1 and 2 from the Arrhenius equation. As determined from least-squares fits of the slopes of Arrhenius plots, the activation energies of compounds 1 and 2 were 0.96 and 0.84 eV, respectively (Figure ) and from these values it is concluded that the observed proton conductivities follow the Vehicle mechanism.

elements.content: Nyquist plot of compound 2 at 80 °C and 95% RH.

elements.content: In order to determine the number of water molecules accumulated at 80 °C and 95% RH, we performed TG analysis for compounds after 12 h of humidification (Figures S21 and S22, ). As shown in , compound 1 shows a gradual weight loss of ∼24% in the temperature range of 50–120 °C and the dehydrated framework is stable up to 230 °C. Similarly, compound 2 shows a weight loss of ∼11.7% in the temperature range of 50–130 °C and the dehydrated framework was found to be stable up to 240 °C. The number of accumulated water molecules inside the frameworks were calculated by corroborating the TGA profiles of humidified samples with the profiles of as-synthesized compounds. The results show that three and one water molecules per formula unit were present in 1 and 2, respectively. The possible reason for the enhancement of conductivity at 80 °C and 95% RH is due to the presence of additional adsorbed water molecules. It is a well-known fact that, in the Vehicle mechanism, the free water molecules act as proton carriers in the form of H3O+ ions. Presumably, the adsorbed water molecules serve as vehicles to carry protons as hydronium ions, as suggested by Kitagawa et al. In addition to this, we also believe that the increased acidity (pK a) of water molecules with an increase in temperature enhances the proton conductivity. To demonstrate the role of water molecules on the resultant conductivity, we performed the proton conduction experiments on D2O-exchanged samples of compounds 1 and 2. For D2O exchange, the as-synthesized samples were pretreated for 24 h at 403 K. The dehydrated compounds were immersed in D2O solvent for 48 h, and the IR spectra were recorded upon drying (Figures S25 and S26, ). The broad peaks observed at around 2500 cm–1 due to the O–D stretching confirms D2O incorporation in the compounds. Impedance analysis of deuterated samples gave conductivity values of 3.8 × 10–8 and 7.26 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 80 °C and 95% RH (Figures S27 and S28, ). As expected, these values are lower than those of hydrated samples due to the heavier isotope substitution.
elements.clean_text: In order to determine the number of water molecules accumulated at 80 °C and 95% RH, we performed TG analysis for compounds after 12 h of humidification (Figures S21 and S22, ). As shown in , compound 1 shows a gradual weight loss of ~24% in the temperature range of 50-120 °C and the dehydrated framework is stable up to 230 °C. Similarly, compound 2 shows a weight loss of ~11.7% in the temperature range of 50-130 °C and the dehydrated framework was found to be stable up to 240 °C. The number of accumulated water molecules inside the frameworks were calculated by corroborating the TGA profiles of humidified samples with the profiles of as-synthesized compounds. The results show that three and one water molecules per formula unit were present in 1 and 2, respectively. The possible reason for the enhancement of conductivity at 80 °C and 95% RH is due to the presence of additional adsorbed water molecules. It is a well-known fact that, in the Vehicle mechanism, the free water molecules act as proton carriers in the form of H3O+ ions. Presumably, the adsorbed water molecules serve as vehicles to carry protons as hydronium ions, as suggested by Kitagawa et al. In addition to this, we also believe that the increased acidity (pK a) of water molecules with an increase in temperature enhances the proton conductivity. To demonstrate the role of water molecules on the resultant conductivity, we performed the proton conduction experiments on D2O-exchanged samples of compounds 1 and 2. For D2O exchange, the as-synthesized samples were pretreated for 24 h at 403 K. The dehydrated compounds were immersed in D2O solvent for 48 h, and the IR spectra were recorded upon drying (Figures S25 and S26, ). The broad peaks observed at around 2500 cm-1 due to the O-D stretching confirms D2O incorporation in the compounds. Impedance analysis of deuterated samples gave conductivity values of 3.8 × 10-8 and 7.26 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 80 °C and 95% RH (Figures S27 and S28, ). As expected, these values are lower than those of hydrated samples due to the heavier isotope substitution.

elements.content: The observed better conductive ability of compound 2 in comparison to 1 might be due to its lower dimensionality and the difference in position of accumulated water molecules in the frameworks (Figure ). To get more insight into the possible water accumulation in the frameworks, we performed Monte Carlo simulations by using the Material Studio 6.1 Sorption Module (details are given in the ). The results show that in compound 1 most of the water molecules accumulated inside the pores (Figures S29 and S30, ), whereas in 2 the accumulation is near the free carboxylic acid groups of pyromellitate ligands between two 1D chains (Figures S31 and , S32, ).
elements.clean_text: The observed better conductive ability of compound 2 in comparison to 1 might be due to its lower dimensionality and the difference in position of accumulated water molecules in the frameworks (Figure ). To get more insight into the possible water accumulation in the frameworks, we performed Monte Carlo simulations by using the Material Studio 6.1 Sorption Module (details are given in the ). The results show that in compound 1 most of the water molecules accumulated inside the pores (Figures S29 and S30, ), whereas in 2 the accumulation is near the free carboxylic acid groups of pyromellitate ligands between two 1D chains (Figures S31 and , S32, ).

elements.content: Expected proton conduction pathways in compounds 1 (left) and 2 (right). The color code is the same as in Figure .
elements.clean_text: 6  Expected proton conduction pathways in compounds 1 (left) and 2 (right). The color code is the same as in Figure .

elements.content: To explore the effect of water on the enhancement of proton conductivity, we performed impedance analysis on both as-synthesized and dehydrated samples at 25 °C by varying the humidity in a controlled manner. The observed conductivities are insignificant at low humidity levels in both cases, and the slight increase in values on increasing humidity suggests that the effect of humidity on conductivity is less at room temperature (Figures S33–S36, ). Interestingly, in the case of activated samples, the conductivity trend with respect to relative humidity resembles the adsorption isotherms of compounds 1 and 2 (Figures S37 and S38, ). To check the effect of water on conductivity at a different temperature, once again we repeated the humidity sweep after setting the temperature at 80 °C for both compounds. In compound 1 the conductivity value was found to be 8.64 × 10–10 S cm–1 at 35% RH (Figure S39, ) and it increased to 2.05 × 10–7 S cm–1 at 95% RH (Figure S40, ). In compound 2 the conductivity attained a value of 1.94 × 10–9 S cm–1 at 35% RH (Figure S41, ), and it drastically increased at high humidity levels and obtained a value of 3.82 × 10–4 S.cm–1 at 95% RH (Figure S42, ). The increased conductivity with an increase in humidity could be due to the improved intergrain conduction by added surface water molecules, as the samples are ground powders which have been pressed into pellets. From these two experiments it is clear that the effect of humidity on proton conductivity is greater at higher temperatures (Figures S43 and S44, ).
elements.clean_text: To explore the effect of water on the enhancement of proton conductivity, we performed impedance analysis on both as-synthesized and dehydrated samples at 25 °C by varying the humidity in a controlled manner. The observed conductivities are insignificant at low humidity levels in both cases, and the slight increase in values on increasing humidity suggests that the effect of humidity on conductivity is less at room temperature (Figures S33-S36, ). Interestingly, in the case of activated samples, the conductivity trend with respect to relative humidity resembles the adsorption isotherms of compounds 1 and 2 (Figures S37 and S38, ). To check the effect of water on conductivity at a different temperature, once again we repeated the humidity sweep after setting the temperature at 80 °C for both compounds. In compound 1 the conductivity value was found to be 8.64 × 10-10 S cm-1 at 35% RH (Figure S39, ) and it increased to 2.05 × 10-7 S cm-1 at 95% RH (Figure S40, ). In compound 2 the conductivity attained a value of 1.94 × 10-9 S cm-1 at 35% RH (Figure S41, ), and it drastically increased at high humidity levels and obtained a value of 3.82 × 10-4 S.cm-1 at 95% RH (Figure S42, ). The increased conductivity with an increase in humidity could be due to the improved intergrain conduction by added surface water molecules, as the samples are ground powders which have been pressed into pellets. From these two experiments it is clear that the effect of humidity on proton conductivity is greater at higher temperatures (Figures S43 and S44, ).

elements.content: To study the effect of temperature on proton conductivity exclusively, we have performed impedance analysis under anhydrous conditions by changing the temperature. The results show that compound 1 exhibits less conductivity in the low-temperature regions (Figure S45, ) and the corresponding values are slightly increased with increasing temperature (7.96 × 10–10 S cm–1 at 80 °C) (Figures S46 and S47, ), whereas compound 2 shows almost negligible conductivity in the low- and high-temperature regions. From this observation we anticipate that under anhydrous conditions only lattice water molecules play an important role in proton conduction. The much smaller conductivity value in the case of compound 2 could be due to the smaller number of lattice water molecules (two H2O molecules) in comparison to compound 1 (five H2O molecules).
elements.clean_text: To study the effect of temperature on proton conductivity exclusively, we have performed impedance analysis under anhydrous conditions by changing the temperature. The results show that compound 1 exhibits less conductivity in the low-temperature regions (Figure S45, ) and the corresponding values are slightly increased with increasing temperature (7.96 × 10-10 S cm-1 at 80 °C) (Figures S46 and S47, ), whereas compound 2 shows almost negligible conductivity in the low- and high-temperature regions. From this observation we anticipate that under anhydrous conditions only lattice water molecules play an important role in proton conduction. The much smaller conductivity value in the case of compound 2 could be due to the smaller number of lattice water molecules (two H2O molecules) in comparison to compound 1 (five H2O molecules).

elements.content: Additionally, as a step toward practical applications, we recorded the time-dependent proton conductivity of compounds 1 and 2 at 80 °C and 95% RH. The proton conductivities remain same for both compounds even after 10 h, with a negligible loss of conductivity (Figure ). To confirm further, the same experiment was performed for three cycles and the obtained results are consistent (Figures S48 and S49, ).
elements.clean_text: Additionally, as a step toward practical applications, we recorded the time-dependent proton conductivity of compounds 1 and 2 at 80 °C and 95% RH. The proton conductivities remain same for both compounds even after 10 h, with a negligible loss of conductivity (Figure ). To confirm further, the same experiment was performed for three cycles and the obtained results are consistent (Figures S48 and S49, ).

elements.content: The PXRD patterns of both compounds after conductivity measurements reveal that there is no change in the structures, showing the durability of the materials, which is an important aspect for practical applications (Figures S50 and S51, ).
elements.clean_text: The PXRD patterns of both compounds after conductivity measurements reveal that there is no change in the structures, showing the durability of the materials, which is an important aspect for practical applications (Figures S50 and S51, ).

elements.content: Proton conductivity of a 2D flexible MOF and a 1D CP at higher temperatures is reported. Compound 1 shows conductivity in the range of previously reported flexible MOFs, whereas 2 exhibits the highest conductivity among the 1D carboxylate-based CPs. Variable-humidity and variable-temperature experiments disclose that the relative humidity plays a vital role in the conductivity at higher temperatures. Time-dependent measurements demonstrate the constant proton-conducting ability of the compounds up to 10 h. These studies emphasize the significance of strong internal H-bonding networks and their effect on proton conductivity properties. Moreover, we anticipate that these compounds could be useful for maintaining constant conductivity at elevated temperatures, which is a prerequisite for a proton exchange membrane in micro fuel cells and micro batteries.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Proton conductivity of a 2D flexible MOF and a 1D CP at higher temperatures is reported. Compound 1 shows conductivity in the range of previously reported flexible MOFs, whereas 2 exhibits the highest conductivity among the 1D carboxylate-based CPs. Variable-humidity and variable-temperature experiments disclose that the relative humidity plays a vital role in the conductivity at higher temperatures. Time-dependent measurements demonstrate the constant proton-conducting ability of the compounds up to 10 h. These studies emphasize the significance of strong internal H-bonding networks and their effect on proton conductivity properties. Moreover, we anticipate that these compounds could be useful for maintaining constant conductivity at elevated temperatures, which is a prerequisite for a proton exchange membrane in micro fuel cells and micro batteries.

cln_elements.content:
We report the proton conduction properties of a 2D flexible MOF and a 1D coordination polymer having the molecular formulas {[Zn(C10H2O8)0.5(C10S2N2H8)]·5H2O]} n (1) and {[Zn(C10H2O8)0.5(C10S2N2H8)]·2H2O]} n (2), respectively. Compounds 1 and 2 show high conductivity values of 2.55 × 10–7 and 4.39 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 80 °C and 95% RH. The conductivity value of compound 1 is in the range of those for previously reported flexible MOFs, and compound 2 shows the highest proton conductivity among the carboxylate-based 1D CPs. The dimensionality and the internal hydrogen bonding connectivity play a vital role in the resultant conductivity. Variable-temperature experiments of both compounds at high humidity reveal that the conductivity values increase with increasing temperature, whereas the variable humidity studies signify the influence of relative humidity on high-temperature proton conductivity. The time-dependent measurements for both compounds demonstrate their ability to retain conductivity up to 10 h.

To study the effect of temperature on proton conductivity exclusively, we have performed impedance analysis under anhydrous conditions by changing the temperature. The results show that compound 1 exhibits less conductivity in the low-temperature regions (Figure S45, ) and the corresponding values are slightly increased with increasing temperature (7.96 × 10–10 S cm–1 at 80 °C) (Figures S46 and S47, ), whereas compound 2 shows almost negligible conductivity in the low- and high-temperature regions. From this observation we anticipate that under anhydrous conditions only lattice water molecules play an important role in proton conduction. The much smaller conductivity value in the case of compound 2 could be due to the smaller number of lattice water molecules (two H2O molecules) in comparison to compound 1 (five H2O molecules).
cln_elements.clean_text:
We report the proton conduction properties of a 2D flexible MOF and a 1D coordination polymer having the molecular formulas {[Zn(C10H2O8)0.5(C10S2N2H8)]⋅5H2O]} n  (1) and {[Zn(C10H2O8)0.5(C10S2N2H8)]⋅2H2O]} n  (2), respectively. Compounds 1 and 2 show high conductivity values of 2.55 × 10-7 and 4.39 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 80 °C and 95% RH. The conductivity value of compound 1 is in the range of those for previously reported flexible MOFs, and compound 2 shows the highest proton conductivity among the carboxylate-based 1D CPs. The dimensionality and the internal hydrogen bonding connectivity play a vital role in the resultant conductivity. Variable-temperature experiments of both compounds at high humidity reveal that the conductivity values increase with increasing temperature, whereas the variable humidity studies signify the influence of relative humidity on high-temperature proton conductivity. The time-dependent measurements for both compounds demonstrate their ability to retain conductivity up to 10 h.

To study the effect of temperature on proton conductivity exclusively, we have performed impedance analysis under anhydrous conditions by changing the temperature. The results show that compound 1 exhibits less conductivity in the low-temperature regions (Figure S45, ) and the corresponding values are slightly increased with increasing temperature (7.96 × 10-10 S cm-1 at 80 °C) (Figures S46 and S47, ), whereas compound 2 shows almost negligible conductivity in the low- and high-temperature regions. From this observation we anticipate that under anhydrous conditions only lattice water molecules play an important role in proton conduction. The much smaller conductivity value in the case of compound 2 could be due to the smaller number of lattice water molecules (two H2O molecules) in comparison to compound 1 (five H2O molecules).
